title: How to Cook a Potato on a Campfire

steps.headline: Make sure you have all the items from the "Ingredients" and "Things You Need".
Cut the potato almost in half, but not completely.
steps.description: Do this step if you wish to add cheese inside the potato. If you don't, this step is optional but will help the potato cook quicker.

steps.headline: Stuff some of the cheese inside if you want.
Wrap up the potato completely in tin foil.
Poke holes through the tin foil with the fork.
steps.description: This will help some of the steam to escape and allows the potato to completely cook.

steps.headline: Find a spot to cook them on the fire, with a long stick or fire poker, that has lots of glowing embers and hot coal.
Carefully place the wrapped potato on the embers.
Surround the potato with the embers, hot coal, and the fire.
Wait at least 5-10 minutes for the potato to cook.
steps.description: To tell if it is cooked, poke the fork into the potato. If it is feels hard, the potato is not cooked. If it is softer and easier to poke, it is cooked.

steps.headline: Wait for the potato to cool a bit before unwrapping the foil.
Cut the potato open once it is unwrapped.
Butter the potato and add salt to taste.

text: Make sure you have all the items from the "Ingredients" and "Things You Need".  Wash and scrub the potato.  Cut the potato almost in half, but not completely. Do this step if you wish to add cheese inside the potato. If you don't, this step is optional but will help the potato cook quicker. Stuff some of the cheese inside if you want. This step is optional. Wrap up the potato completely in tin foil.  Poke holes through the tin foil with the fork. This will help some of the steam to escape and allows the potato to completely cook. Find a spot to cook them on the fire, with a long stick or fire poker, that has lots of glowing embers and hot coal.  Carefully place the wrapped potato on the embers.  Surround the potato with the embers, hot coal, and the fire.  Wait at least 5-10 minutes for the potato to cook. To tell if it is cooked, poke the fork into the potato. If it is feels hard, the potato is not cooked. If it is softer and easier to poke, it is cooked. Wait for the potato to cool a bit before unwrapping the foil.  Cut the potato open once it is unwrapped.  Butter the potato and add salt to taste.  Enjoy eating your fire-baked potato!
